{{update|date=February 2013}} Since the [[Declaration of Independence (Israel)|founding of the State of Israel]], relatively few women have served in the [[Cabinet of Israel|Israeli government]], and fewer still have served in the leading ministerial offices. While Israel is one of a small number of countries where a woman—[[Golda Meir]]—has served as [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]], it is behind most Western countries in the representation of women in both the parliament and government.
{{As of|2018}}, women comprise 28% of Israel's 120-member [[Knesset]]. For comparison (as of 2004), the female ratio in the Arab world is 6.4%, in [[European Union]] average is 17.6% and in [[Scandinavia]] 40% "and rising".<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Society_&_Culture/women2004.html Women In Israel] Jewish Virtual Library</ref> In the United States of America, women comprise only 19.3% of the House of Representatives. Female representation varies significantly by demographics: most female politicians have represented secular parties, while very few have come from Arab or religious Jewish parties.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Society_&_Culture/Women_in_public_life.html Women in Public Life] Jewish Virtual Library</ref><ref>[http://www.knesset.gov.il/mk/eng/MKIndex_Current_eng.asp?view=3 Current Female Knesset Members] Knesset website</ref>
== Women in the leading jobs in the government == {| class="toccolours" border="0" cellpadding="3" style=" margin: 0 1em 1em 0;" align=right |-bgcolor="#87cefa" |'''Portfolio'''||'''Name'''|| width=80|'''Dates in office''' |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]]||[[Golda Meir]]||align=center|1969–1974 |- |[[Deputy leaders of Israel#Vice Prime Minister|Vice Prime Minister]] || [[Tzipi Livni]]||align=center|2006-2009 |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Communications Minister of Israel|Communications Minister]]||[[Shulamit Aloni]]|| align=center|1993–1996 |- | ||[[Limor Livnat]]||align=center|1996–1999 |- | ||[[Dalia Itzik]]||align=center|2005 |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Education Minister of Israel|Education Minister]]||[[Shulamit Aloni]] ||align=center|1992–1993 |- |- | ||[[Limor Livnat]]||align=center|2001–2006 |- | ||[[Yuli Tamir]]||align=center|2006-2009 |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Minister]]|| [[Golda Meir]] ||align=center|1956–1966 |- | ||[[Tzipi Livni]]||align=center|2006–2009 |- |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Health Minister of Israel|Health Minister]]||[[Shoshana Arbeli-Almozlino]]||align=center|1986–1988 |- |- | ||[[Yael German]]||align=center|2013-2014 |- |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Internal Affairs Minister of Israel|Internal Affairs Minister]]||[[Golda Meir]]||align=center|1970 |- |[[Justice Minister of Israel|Justice Minister]]||[[Tzipi Livni]]||align=center|2004–2006, 2013-2014 |- |- | ||[[Ayelet Shaked]]||align=center|since 2015 |- |-bgcolor="#efefef" |[[Labour Minister of Israel|Labour Minister]]||[[Golda Meir]]||align=center|1949–1956 |- |- | ||[[Ora Namir]]||align=center|1992-1996 |}
[[Golda Meir]] is the only woman to serve as the [[Prime Minister of Israel]]. She was chosen for the job just before the [[Israeli legislative election, 1969|1969 elections]] following the death of [[Levi Eshkol]], and ended her job in 1974. She and [[Tzipi Livni]] are the only women who served as [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Affairs Ministers]], Meir having served in the job for 10 years—from 1956 to 1966. Livni is the only woman to serve in the second most important job in the Israeli government, [[Deputy leaders of Israel#Vice Prime Minister|Vice Prime Minister]].
Once Golda Meir resigned in 1974, it was another 12 years until another woman was appointed as a minister with a portfolio, when [[Shoshana Arbeli-Almozlino]] was appointed [[Health Minister of Israel|Health Minister]], and 18 years until a woman was appointed to any other portfolio, [[Education Minister of Israel|Education Minister]].
After Golda Meir, the leading jobs which women held are as follows: [[Education Minister of Israel|Education Minister]] for a total of 9 years (5 of them by [[Limor Livnat]], 3 years by [[Yuli Tamir]] and 1 year by [[Shulamit Aloni]]), and [[Communications Minister of Israel|Minister of Communications]], also for a total of 7 years (6 years by [[Shulamit Aloni]] and [[Limor Livnat]], and 1 year by [[Dalia Itzik]]). [[Tzipi Livni]] was acting [[Justice Minister of Israel|Minister of Justice]] for a month, and then Minister of Justice for almost a year and a half. [[Ayelet Shaked]] was appointed as Minister of Justice in 2015.
Although a few women did succeed in reaching the leading posts in the Israeli government, a number of them hadn't ever been held by women, such as [[Defense Minister of Israel|Defense Minister]], [[Internal Security Minister of Israel|Internal Security Minister]], [[Finance Ministry (Israel)|Finance Minister]].
== Historical overview == ===Until the 1970s=== [[Image:Golda Meir2.jpg|thumb|[[Golda Meir]], at a meeting in the [[White House]], 1973]] From the first Israeli government until the 12th, [[Golda Meir]] was the only woman in the Israeli government (though not the parliament). Golda Meir, who started out as a secretary of the Women's Labour Council of Histadrut, and later became the head of the [[Jewish Agency for Israel]]'s political department, and then an ambassador to the [[Soviet Union]], came back to Israel in 1949 after she was elected to the [[Knesset]], and served as the Israeli Minister of Labor. She held this job for 7 years under a number of Prime Ministers, until in 1956 she became Foreign Minister, a job she held for 10 years until 1966.
After 3 years, in which she wasn't a member of the Israeli government, she was chosen as the head the [[Alignment (political party)|Alignment party]] and as Prime Minister, and she was voted as Prime Minister again in the [[Israeli legislative election, 1969|1969 elections]], when the party got the highest number of seats in the Knesset. Despite being a woman, she wasn't known as a [[Feminism|Feminist]], and she didn't appoint any other women to positions in the government.
During Golda Meir's time, the number of woman members of Knesset was around 10–14 on average (out of 120), mostly from [[Mapai]] and its successor parties. In the elections during which Golda Meir was to become prime minister, only 8 women got into the Knesset.
=== The 1970s ===
After the [[Israeli legislative election, 1973|1973 elections]], Golda Meir resigned from her position as prime minister as the result of protests after the [[Yom Kippur War]], and [[Yitzhak Rabin]] was chosen to succeed her. In 1974, he appointed [[Shulamit Aloni]] as a [[minister without portfolio]]. She held this position for 5 months, until she resigned in protest over the appointment of [[Yitzhak Rafael]] as the [[Religious Services Minister of Israel|Religious Services Minister]], despite the fact that he was suspected of having accepted bribes.
=== After the 1970s === In 2015, the first Israeli political party dedicated to ultra-Orthodox women was unveiled, called "B’Zhutan: Haredi Women Making Change."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel-election-2015/.premium-1.637916|title=Israel's first ever ultra-Orthodox women’s party makes bold debut|date=20 January 2015|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref>
